text: What does a solid red traffic light mean?
choices: Stop completely and remain stopped until green
Stop, then proceed if clear
Slow down and proceed with caution
Yield to oncoming traffic
explanation: A solid red light requires drivers to stop completely and remain stopped until the light turns green. Proceeding on red without a green signal is illegal.

text: What should you do when you see a solid green traffic light?
choices: Proceed if the intersection is clear
Speed up to get through quickly
Stop and wait for other vehicles
Honk your horn and continue
explanation: A solid green light means you may proceed through the intersection, but only after ensuring it is safe and clear of pedestrians and vehicles.

text: What does a solid yellow traffic light indicate?
choices: The light is about to turn red; prepare to stop
Speed up to get through the intersection
Slow down but continue through
Stop immediately regardless of position
explanation: A solid yellow light warns that the signal is about to turn red. You should stop if you can do so safely, not speed up to beat the red light.

text: At a red light, when are you permitted to turn right in Texas?
choices: After coming to a complete stop and yielding to traffic and pedestrians, unless a sign prohibits it
Whenever there is no oncoming traffic
Only when a green arrow appears
Never, right turns on red are illegal in Texas
explanation: In Texas, you may turn right on red after stopping completely and yielding to all traffic and pedestrians, unless a sign specifically prohibits the turn.

text: You are at a red light in the left lane. Can you turn left onto a one-way street in Texas?
choices: Yes, after stopping and yielding to traffic and pedestrians, if no sign prohibits it
No, left turns on red are never permitted
Yes, but only from a one-way street onto another one-way street
Yes, without stopping if the intersection is clear
explanation: In Texas, you may turn left on red only when turning from a one-way street onto another one-way street, after stopping completely and yielding to all traffic.

text: What should you do if you are already in an intersection when the light turns yellow?
choices: Continue through the intersection safely
Stop immediately in the intersection
Back up to the stop line
Speed up to clear the intersection quickly
explanation: If you are already in the intersection when the light turns yellow, you should continue through safely. Stopping in the intersection creates a hazard.

text: At a red light, you want to turn right, but a pedestrian is crossing the street you're turning onto. What must you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to completely cross before turning
Turn slowly behind the pedestrian
Honk to warn the pedestrian and proceed
Turn in front of the pedestrian if moving slowly
explanation: You must yield to all pedestrians in the crosswalk before making a right turn on red. Pedestrians always have the right of way in crosswalks.

text: What is the primary purpose of a yellow traffic light?
choices: To warn that the light is about to turn red
To allow drivers to speed up
To indicate a malfunctioning signal
To give pedestrians time to cross
explanation: The yellow light serves as a warning that the green phase is ending and the light will soon turn red, giving drivers time to safely stop.

text: If a traffic signal displays both red and yellow lights at the same time, what does this indicate?
choices: The signal is malfunctioning; treat it as a stop sign
Proceed with extreme caution
The light is about to turn green
You may turn right only
explanation: When a traffic signal displays conflicting lights or appears to be malfunctioning, you must treat the intersection as if it has a stop sign at every approach.

text: When approaching a green light, why should you still scan the intersection before entering?
choices: Other drivers may run their red light or pedestrians may be crossing
Green lights are only advisory
You must always stop at green lights first
Green lights mean yield to all traffic
explanation: Even with a green light, you must ensure the intersection is clear because other drivers may run the red light or pedestrians may still be in the crosswalk.

text: You arrive at a red light behind several cars. When the light turns green, when should you proceed?
choices: When the vehicle ahead of you has moved and it's safe to proceed
Immediately when the light turns green
After counting to three
When you hear other cars honking
explanation: You should proceed when the vehicle in front of you has moved and you can do so safely, maintaining appropriate following distance.

text: Can you enter an intersection on a green light if traffic ahead is backed up and you cannot completely clear the intersection?
choices: No, you must wait until you can completely clear the intersection
Yes, as long as the light is green
Yes, if you enter before the light turns yellow
Yes, but only if you're turning
explanation: You must not enter an intersection, even on a green light, if traffic conditions prevent you from clearing it completely. This prevents blocking the intersection or gridlock.

text: What does a solid red traffic signal mean for pedestrians?
choices: Do not begin crossing; wait for the walk signal
Cross quickly before traffic starts
Cross only if no vehicles are present
You have the right of way to cross
explanation: When the traffic signal is red for vehicles in your direction, pedestrians should wait for their walk signal rather than assuming it's safe to cross.

text: During heavy traffic, you enter an intersection legally on a yellow light but cannot clear it before the light turns red. Traffic from other directions begins to move. What should you do?
choices: Continue clearing the intersection safely; you have the right of way
Stop in the middle of the intersection
Reverse back to your stop line
Turn to exit through a different street
explanation: Once you have legally entered an intersection, you must clear it even if the light turns red. Other traffic must yield to vehicles already in the intersection.

text: What should you do if a traffic signal's green light has been on for a while as you approach?
choices: Be prepared to stop as the light may change soon
Speed up to make sure you get through
Continue at the same speed
Slow down to 5 mph
explanation: A stale green light that has been on for some time may change soon, so you should be prepared to stop safely if needed.

text: At a red light, where must you stop your vehicle?
choices: At the stop line or before entering the crosswalk
In the middle of the intersection
Just before entering the intersection
Anywhere you can see the signal
explanation: You must stop at the marked stop line, or if there is no line, before entering the crosswalk or intersection to avoid blocking pedestrians.

text: If you accidentally run a red light and are already in the intersection, what should you do?
choices: Continue through the intersection quickly and safely
Stop immediately in the intersection
Back up to the stop line
Turn onto a side street
explanation: If you're already in the intersection, stopping creates a greater hazard. You should clear the intersection quickly and safely, then drive more carefully.

text: You are approaching a green light but notice the crosswalk is full of pedestrians still crossing. What should you do?
choices: Wait for all pedestrians to clear the crosswalk before proceeding
Proceed slowly through the pedestrians
Honk to clear the crosswalk
Drive around the pedestrians
explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk, even if you have a green light. Wait until they have completely crossed.

text: What is the minimum duration you should expect for a yellow light at a typical intersection?
choices: 3 to 6 seconds depending on the speed limit
Always exactly 3 seconds
10 seconds or more
1 to 2 seconds
explanation: Yellow light duration typically ranges from 3 to 6 seconds based on the approach speed and intersection design, giving drivers adequate time to stop safely.

text: You stop at a red light on a steep downhill grade. When the light turns green, the vehicle ahead of you starts to roll backward. What should you do?
choices: Stay back and honk your horn to alert the driver
Move forward to push their vehicle
Quickly change lanes to avoid them
Assume they will stop rolling
explanation: Maintain a safe following distance and alert the driver with your horn. Never move forward into a vehicle, even when you have a green light.

text: What does a green arrow signal mean?
choices: You may proceed in the direction of the arrow without yielding
You may proceed but must yield to oncoming traffic
You should prepare to stop
You may only proceed if no other vehicles are present
explanation: A green arrow is a protected signal that gives you the right of way to proceed in the indicated direction without yielding to conflicting traffic.

text: You see a green left arrow along with a red circular signal. What should you do?
choices: You may turn left only; straight and right movements are prohibited
You may proceed straight or turn left
You must stop completely
You may proceed in any direction
explanation: A green arrow with a red circular signal means only movements in the direction of the arrow are permitted; all other movements must stop.

text: What does a yellow arrow signal indicate?
choices: The protected turn is ending; prepare to stop or yield
You may proceed with the turn
Turn only if the intersection is clear
The signal is malfunctioning
explanation: A yellow arrow warns that the protected turn phase is ending. You should prepare to stop, or complete your turn if already committed.

text: What does a red arrow signal mean?
choices: You must stop and cannot proceed in the direction of the arrow
You may proceed after yielding
You may turn after stopping
Slow down and proceed with caution
explanation: A red arrow means you must stop and remain stopped. You cannot turn in the direction of the arrow, even after stopping.

text: You are in a left turn lane with a green circular signal but no green arrow. What must you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians before turning
Proceed with your turn immediately
Wait for a green arrow before turning
You cannot turn left; the signal prohibits it
explanation: A green circular signal without an arrow is a permissive turn. You may turn left but must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

text: At an intersection, you have a green arrow to turn left. Oncoming traffic has what signal?
choices: A red signal preventing them from entering the intersection
A green signal allowing them to proceed
A yellow caution signal
A flashing red signal
explanation: When you have a green arrow, it is a protected turn meaning oncoming traffic has a red signal and must stop.

text: The signal changes from a green arrow to a green circular signal while you're waiting to turn left. What has changed?
choices: You must now yield to oncoming traffic when turning
You no longer can turn left
You have more right of way than before
Nothing; both signals mean the same thing
explanation: Changing from a green arrow to a green circular signal means your turn is no longer protected. You must now yield to oncoming traffic.

text: Can you make a right turn when you see a red arrow pointing right?
choices: No, you must wait for a green signal or arrow
Yes, after stopping and yielding
Yes, if no traffic is coming
Yes, red arrows are only advisory
explanation: A red arrow specifically prohibits movement in that direction. You cannot turn right on a red arrow, even after stopping.

text: You are turning left on a green arrow. A pedestrian enters the crosswalk against their signal. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian even though you have the right of way
Continue; you have the green arrow
Honk and proceed slowly
Swerve around the pedestrian
explanation: Even with a protected green arrow, you must always yield to pedestrians in the roadway to avoid a collision, regardless of signal status.

text: What is the difference between a green arrow and a green circular signal for turning?
choices: A green arrow is protected; a green circular signal requires yielding to oncoming traffic
They mean the same thing
A green arrow requires stopping first
A green circular signal gives more right of way
explanation: A green arrow provides a protected turn with right of way, while a green circular signal is a permissive turn requiring you to yield to oncoming traffic.

text: You have a green left arrow. Halfway through your turn, the arrow turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn safely and clear the intersection
Stop in the middle of your turn
Speed up dramatically
Reverse back to the stop line
explanation: If you've already started your turn legally, you should complete it safely and clear the intersection even if the signal changes.

text: At a complex intersection, you see a green circular signal and a separate red arrow pointing left. What can you do?
choices: Go straight or turn right, but not left
Turn in any direction
Only go straight
Only turn left
explanation: The green circular signal permits straight and right movements, but the red left arrow specifically prohibits left turns.

text: You are waiting to turn left on a green circular signal. Oncoming traffic is heavy. The light turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn when oncoming traffic stops for their yellow light
Wait at the stop line; do not enter the intersection
Turn in front of oncoming traffic quickly
Abandon the turn and go straight
explanation: If you're already in the intersection waiting to turn, you should complete your turn safely when oncoming traffic yields for the yellow light.

text: When turning right on a green circular signal, what must you watch for?
choices: Pedestrians crossing and vehicles turning left from the opposite direction
Only vehicles behind you
Only the traffic signal
Nothing; you have complete right of way
explanation: Even on a green signal, you must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and watch for vehicles from the opposite direction making permissive left turns.

text: What does it mean if you see a green right arrow?
choices: You have a protected right turn with no conflicting traffic
You must turn right; going straight is prohibited
You may turn right after yielding
The signal is for bikes only
explanation: A green right arrow indicates a protected right turn phase where pedestrian and conflicting traffic are stopped.

text: You're at a T-intersection where you must turn either left or right. You have a red signal but no arrows. Can you turn after stopping?
choices: You may turn right on red after stopping and yielding, unless prohibited by a sign
You cannot turn in either direction on red
You may turn in either direction
You may only turn left
explanation: At a T-intersection with a red signal, standard right-turn-on-red rules apply unless posted otherwise, but left turns on red are not permitted unless turning from one-way to one-way.

text: While waiting to turn left with a green circular signal, you should position your vehicle how?
choices: In the intersection with wheels straight, not turned
Before the stop line with wheels turned left
In the intersection with wheels turned left
Partially in the intersection
explanation: You should position your vehicle in the intersection with wheels straight so that if you're rear-ended, you won't be pushed into oncoming traffic.

text: A traffic signal shows a yellow arrow for your left turn, but you haven't entered the intersection yet. What should you do?
choices: Stop if you can do so safely; the protected turn is ending
Enter the intersection quickly to make the turn
Proceed slowly with caution
Treat it as a green arrow
explanation: A yellow arrow means the protected turn phase is ending. If you haven't entered the intersection, you should stop if you can safely do so.

text: Why might an intersection use a red arrow instead of just a red circular signal?
choices: To specifically prohibit turns while other movements might be allowed
To indicate a longer red phase
To warn of a dangerous intersection
Red arrows and red circles mean exactly the same thing
explanation: Red arrows are used to specifically prohibit certain movements while other directions might have different signal phases.

text: When you see a green arrow pointing left, which direction should you turn?
choices: Left
Right
Either left or right
Straight ahead
explanation: A green arrow pointing left means you should turn left. The arrow indicates the specific direction you may proceed.

text: What does a flashing red traffic signal mean?
choices: Stop, then proceed when safe, treating it like a stop sign
Slow down and proceed with caution
The signal is broken; proceed normally
Stop and wait for a green light
explanation: A flashing red signal means you must come to a complete stop, then proceed when safe, just like at a stop sign.

text: What does a flashing yellow traffic signal mean?
choices: Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop, then proceed when safe
Speed up to clear the intersection
The signal will soon turn red
explanation: A flashing yellow signal means you should slow down, be alert, and proceed through the intersection with caution.

text: You approach an intersection with a flashing red signal while cross traffic has a flashing yellow signal. What should you do?
choices: Stop completely, then proceed when safe after yielding to cross traffic
Proceed with caution at the same time as cross traffic
Stop and wait for the signal to turn green
Proceed without stopping since you see the yellow
explanation: A flashing red requires you to stop and yield to all traffic, including vehicles with the flashing yellow who have the right of way.

text: When are you most likely to encounter flashing traffic signals?
choices: Late at night or during low traffic periods, or when signals are malfunctioning
During rush hour
Only during emergency situations
During school hours
explanation: Flashing signals are commonly used during late night hours when full signal cycles aren't needed, or when a signal malfunctions.

text: At an intersection, you have a flashing yellow signal. What right of way do you have?
choices: Proceed with caution but yield to any vehicles already in the intersection
You have complete right of way over all other traffic
You must stop and wait for other vehicles
You must yield to all traffic entering from any direction
explanation: A flashing yellow gives you the right to proceed with caution, but you must still yield to vehicles already lawfully in the intersection.

text: If all signals at an intersection are flashing red in all directions, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat the intersection as a four-way stop
Proceed with caution without stopping
The first to arrive has right of way without stopping
Wait for police to direct traffic
explanation: When all approaches have flashing red signals, the intersection functions as an all-way stop, with normal stop sign rules applying.

text: You approach an intersection where the signal is completely dark with no lights showing. How should you proceed?
choices: Treat it as a four-way stop and stop before entering
Proceed normally as if it were green
Slow down but don't stop unless you see traffic
Only the main road has right of way
explanation: A completely dark or non-functioning signal should be treated as an all-way stop sign, requiring all traffic to stop before proceeding.

text: What is the key difference between a flashing yellow and a solid yellow signal?
choices: Flashing yellow means proceed with caution; solid yellow means prepare to stop
They mean the same thing
Flashing yellow means stop; solid yellow means go
Flashing yellow is more urgent than solid yellow
explanation: A flashing yellow is a warning to proceed cautiously, while a solid yellow indicates the signal is changing and you should prepare to stop.

text: At an intersection with a flashing red signal, two vehicles from different directions arrive at exactly the same time. Who has the right of way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle on the left
The larger vehicle
The vehicle that flashes its headlights first
explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously at a flashing red (treated as a stop sign), the vehicle on the right has the right of way.

text: During a power outage, traffic signals are completely out. You arrive at a busy intersection at the same time as several other vehicles. What governs right-of-way?
choices: Standard four-way stop rules and basic right-of-way principles
The largest vehicle goes first
Whoever proceeds first has the right of way
Everyone should wait for police
explanation: Non-functioning signals create a four-way stop situation. Right of way follows normal stop sign rules: first to arrive, or vehicle on right if simultaneous.

text: What does a steady WALK signal mean for pedestrians?
choices: Begin crossing the street
Finish crossing if already in the street
Do not cross
Cross only if no vehicles are present
explanation: A steady WALK signal indicates that pedestrians may begin crossing the street in the direction of the signal.

text: What does a steady DON'T WALK or raised hand signal mean?
choices: Do not start crossing the street
Stop immediately wherever you are
Cross quickly
The signal is for vehicles only
explanation: A steady DON'T WALK or raised hand signal means pedestrians should not begin crossing, though those already crossing should complete their crossing.

text: What does a flashing DON'T WALK signal mean?
choices: Do not start crossing; finish crossing if already in the street
Start crossing quickly
Stop in the middle of the street
The pedestrian signal is broken
explanation: A flashing DON'T WALK means do not start crossing. Pedestrians already in the crosswalk should continue and finish crossing safely.

text: You are a pedestrian and the WALK signal turns to a flashing DON'T WALK when you are halfway across a wide street. What should you do?
choices: Continue crossing to the other side or to a safety island
Run back to where you started
Stop and wait in the middle of the street
Run across quickly
explanation: If the signal changes while you're crossing, continue to the other side or a pedestrian safety island. Do not run or turn back.

text: What does a pedestrian countdown timer indicate?
choices: The number of seconds remaining to finish crossing before the DON'T WALK phase
The number of seconds until WALK signal appears
The speed you should walk
The number of pedestrians allowed to cross
explanation: A countdown timer shows how many seconds pedestrians have to complete their crossing before the don't walk phase ends and traffic may begin.

text: As a driver with a green light, can you proceed through the crosswalk if the pedestrian signal shows DON'T WALK but a pedestrian is still crossing?
choices: No, you must yield to any pedestrian in the crosswalk regardless of signal
Yes, the pedestrian is crossing illegally
Yes, if you honk first
Yes, but proceed very slowly
explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk, regardless of what the pedestrian signal shows or whose signal shows green.

text: A pedestrian countdown timer shows 3 seconds remaining as you approach the crosswalk. Should you start crossing?
choices: No, do not start crossing if you cannot make it across safely
Yes, you have 3 seconds to cross
Yes, run across quickly
Yes, traffic will wait for you
explanation: If the countdown shows insufficient time to safely cross, do not enter the crosswalk. Wait for the next WALK signal.

text: What should drivers do when they see a pedestrian signal showing WALK for a crosswalk they want to turn through?
choices: Wait for pedestrians to cross; they have the right of way
Turn slowly behind the pedestrians
Honk to warn pedestrians
Proceed; the WALK signal is not for drivers
explanation: When the pedestrian signal shows WALK, pedestrians have the right of way in that crosswalk and drivers must yield before turning.

text: At an intersection with pedestrian signals, you have a green left arrow. What should the pedestrian signal show?
choices: DON'T WALK, preventing pedestrians from crossing into your path
WALK, giving pedestrians the right of way
Flashing DON'T WALK
No signal
explanation: A green arrow for vehicles is a protected turn, meaning pedestrian signals should show DON'T WALK to prevent conflicts.

text: A pedestrian signal shows WALK but the traffic signal for vehicles shows green in the same direction. A driver wants to turn right. Who has the legal right of way?
choices: The pedestrian; drivers must yield when turning
The driver with the green light
Whoever reaches the crosswalk first
Neither; it's a signal malfunction
explanation: Even though drivers have a green light, they must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk who have a WALK signal when making turns.
